chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: In this tutorial I'll show you what HDR is and how to add it to your OpenGL project.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: So up until now all our colors had a range between 0 and 1.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: But we can get better and more realistic results if we go outside this range.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: For example, we can simply make a white light twice as bright as the normal white light

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: by giving the color 222 in RGB.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: The problem is that on monitors do not support HDR.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: So we instead have to compress this HDR range to our normal range.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: This process of compression is called tone mapping.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: So let's first make sure we have a frame buffer for rendering our scene

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: and check that it has gamma correction on it.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: You can watch my previous tutorials if you don't already have this.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Now we want to make sure that the texture used for our frame buffer

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: has one of the following color configurations.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Since otherwise, OpenGL will automatically clamp all colors between 0 and 1 and we don't want that.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Next, change the color of your light to something insanely high and start the program.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: If you've done everything correctly, you should see something like this.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Now let's write in the tone mapping algorithm so stuff doesn't look so bright.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: We'll go into the fragment shader of our frame buffer and first define an exposure variable.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: So what is exposure?

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Well, exposure basically represents how much light we let into our virtual camera.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: The lower the exposure, the less light we will get.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: The higher the exposure, the more light we will get.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Based on this exposure, we can get different visual results for our scenes.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Here's an example where the exposure changes based on the surrounding lighting.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Inside the exposure is really high so that you can see the little light that is present

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: in the underground area.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Well, outside the exposure is small in order to not be blinded by all the light.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: But you can see that when going outside, for a split second,

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: the exposure is in the process of changing and so it's still blinding for a moment.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: And when going inside, you can't see that much for a second.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: So now let's finish writing the code for the tone mapping algorithm

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: and start the program with an exposure level of one.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: This results bring me to the second way that you can think of exposure.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: When your exposure is low like here, bright lights won't hinder your ability to see details.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Well, if the exposure is high, lights will hide away all the detail of your scene.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Now is it for this tutorial?

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: If you need help or want to chat with like-minded people,

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: check out my Discord server.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: If you enjoy my content, consider supporting me on Patreon.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: As always, the source code and all sources and resources used are in the description.

chunks.title: HDR (High-Dynamic-Range).mp4
chunks.text: Bye!
